abstractText: Research on extraterrestrial materials plays a critical role in formulating the science rationale and design for spacecraft missions, and, conversely, spaceflight holds great promise for solving perplexing problems in meteoritics. The connections between meteoritics and sample-return missions are obvious: Meteorite research can define sampling strategies, the capabilities of sampling devices, acceptable levels of chemical contamination and physical alteration of samples, and the conditions under which samples are stored prior to and during recovery. For their part, sample-return missions can provide geologic context for meteorites, increased sampling diversity (including materials not sampled as meteorites, such as unconsolidated regolith, ices, and atmosphere), calibration for crater-counting chronology, and ground truth for remote sensing measurements of meteorite parent bodies. Meteoritics also relates to spacecraft flyby, rendezvous, and lander missions that do not necessarily return samples. Specific illustrations of this mutual relationship, based on a selection of recent or planned spacecraft missions include: Identifying source asteroid classes for ordinary and carbonaceous chondrites and reconstructing their thermal and collisional histories (Galileo, NEAR, Clementine 11, and Muses-C); determining the extent to which cometary dust and interstellar grains are found as interplanetary dust particles and assessing volatile abundances, isotopic compositions, and molecular species in cometary nuclei (Stardust and Rosetta); understanding the compositions of ancient Martian crust and the mantle sources for SNC meteorites, as well as inventorying the planet's volatile reservoirs and interactions (Mars Pathfinder, Mars Global Surveyor, and Mars Volatiles and Climate Surveyor); assessing whether lunar meteorites provide a more representative chemical sampling of the highlands crust and of mare volcanism than do Apollo samples (Galileo, Clementine, and Lunar Prospector). Spaceflight is the first priority of the space agencies that fund most research on extraterrestrial materials, and the continued level of support for such research may be linked, in part, to its use in exploration by spacecraft. INTRODUCTION In a very real sense, the science of meteoritics informs spaceA young and impressionable moth once set his heart on a certain star. He told his mother about this and she counseled him to set his heart on a bridge lamp instead.. . . "You don't get anywhere chasing stars,'' said the moth's father. But the moth would not heed the words of either parent.. . . Every evening at dusk when the star came out he would start flying toward it and every morning at dawn he would crawl back home worn out with his vain endeavor. He never did reach the star, but he went right on trying, night after night, and when he was a very, very old moth he began to think that he really had reached the star and he went around saying so. This gave him a deep and lasting pleasure, and he lived to a great old age. His parents and his brothers and sisters had all been burned to death when they were quite young. (James Thurber, The Thurber Carnival) It is time, past time really, that the meteoritics community involve itself more fully in spaceflight or, to use Thurber's metaphor, that we reach for the stars (hopefully more successfully than did the moth in the passage above). We have learned a great deal by having the stars come to us, so to speak, and this essential work must continue. However, a deeper understanding of meteorites and interplanetary dust particles also requires that we have geologic (i.e., asteroidal, cometary, or planetary) context for these samples, and that can be best provided from spacecraft flyby, rendezvous, lander, and sample-return missions to their parent bodies. From a pragmatic view, spaceflight is the first priority of the space agencies that fund most research on extraterrestrial materials, and participation of meteoriticists in the design and execution of these missions is desirable to insure the continued health of this discipline (Thurber has nicely spelled out the perils of limited vision). craft missions and, conversely, spaceflight holds great potential for informing meteoritics. This paper will illustrate this mutual relationship by summarizing a few important problems whose resolution may be nearly at hand because of recent or planned missions to meteorite parent bodies. More specifically, I will discuss the critical role of extraterrestrial materials research in formulating the scientific basis and design of spacecraft missions as well as consider what kind of scientific insights the meteoritics community might reasonably expect to gain in return. The specific missions highlighted are described briefly in the Appendix. Because the number of flown or approved missions that are directly relevant to meteoritics is modest, the list of meteorite problems they can address is illustrative rather than all-inclusive. Indeed, my purpose is to prompt meteoriticists to become involved in expanding the number of relevant missions. Returned samples from asteroids, comets, planets, and the Moon are, of course, especially relevant to meteoritics, and the scientific rationale for sample-return missions has been made repeatedly (Drake et al., 1987; Gooding et al., 1989; Ryder et al., 1989; Swindle et al., 1991) and amply demonstrated by lunar samples from the Apollo and Luna programs. Extraterrestrial materials research provides critical information that is used to define sampling strategies and the capabilities of sampling devices. The kinds of analyses to which returned samples will be subjected determine acceptable levels of chemical contamination or physical alteration of the samples as well as the conditions under which the samples must be stored during cruise and recovery. Conversely, sample-return missions will provide geologic context for meteorites and increase sampling di-
title: The role of meteoritics in spaceflight missions and vice versa
